communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1616660-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on “Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request” on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request

If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-0] please enter [1195846-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-1] please enter [1195846-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000
Case Type:
FOIPA
Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)

The FBI’s FOIPA Program is searching the FBI’s indices for potentially responsive documents.

You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.


Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system, and the FBI receives a voluminous amount of requests on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Our complex requests are further divided into small (51-250 pages), medium (251-500 pages), large (501-4,999), and extra-large (over 5,000 pages) sub-tracks.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  The more potentially responsive pages a request has, the more complex it becomes, greatly increasing the time required for processing. Generally, the larger the file, the longer it takes to process.
Currently, simple track cases average approximately 230 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Complex requests in the small processing track are currently averaging 1,085 days from the date of receipt for processing, those in the medium processing track are currently averaging 1,310 days, those in the large processing track are currently averaging approximately 2,010 days, and those in the extra-large track are averaging 2,370 days  .


Respectfully,


Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

title: Health and mental healthcare and juvenile justice (Office Of Juvenile Justice; Washington Department Of Children Youth And Families)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Health and mental healthcare and juvenile justice (Office Of Juvenile Justice; Washington Department Of Children Youth And Families)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern,

This is a request for records under your state public records law.  I am requesting copies of public records regarding health and behavioural health service delivery in youth correctional facilities in your jurisdiction, to inform a comparative research project regarding health and mental health care delivery in juvenile detention facilities across the US. Specifically, I request information regarding the following:
1. Name and contact details for those responsible for health and behavioural health services provisions at all locations where juveniles are incarcerated within your jurisdiction.
2. Regulations, policies and procedures that govern the operation of health and behavioral health provision for juveniles incarcerated within your jurisdiction. This includes health intake, room confinement, medication management,  access to specialist and dental services, discharge planning services, and other health and behavioral health related policies.
3. Contracts from January 1, 2021 to the time the request is filled between your agency and any healthcare provider including both physical health and behavioral health. 
4. Records concerning your jurisdiction’s most recent application to Centre for Medicaid Services (CMS) for an 1115 Medicaid waiver (if applicable), and any response, with specifically focus on how and whether such a waiver applies to provision of Medicaid funded services for detained juveniles.
5. Records relating to financing for health and behavioural health care delivery in your jurisdiction. 

I request the records be provided electronically. If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me. However, I would also like to request a waiver of all fees in that the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of the administration of juvenile justice. This information is not being sought for commercial purposes.

If access to the records I am requesting will take longer than allowed by statute, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies of the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Thank you for considering my request.

Sincerely,

Tess Kelly 
Fellow, Harvard FXB Centre for Health and Human Rights 

Joshua Dankoff
Director of Strategic Initiatives
Citizens for Juvenile Justice
617.338.1050

title: Code Enforcement's Refusal to Enforce Laws Requiring Deadbolts at the Baltimore Hotel owned by-AIDS Healthcare Foundation

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Code Enforcement's Refusal to Enforce Laws Requiring Deadbolts at the Baltimore Hotel owned by-AIDS Healthcare Foundation
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide all notes, entries, photos, videos, reports, complaints, emails, text messages, and other communications, concerning the following:

1.Code Enforcement Complaint #897099, filed April 30, 2024, in which a tenant complained he did not have a deadbolt, and more than 100 other units at the AIDS Healthcare Foundation's Baltimore Hotel did not have deadbolts
2. Inspector Tony Robles noted that on May 9, 2024, he went to the Baltimore and spoke with the complaining tenant, and took photos.  Please provide all of those notes, documents, photos or videos.
3. All communications regarding the February 2022 inspection by Tony Robles of the Baltimore, during which he noted over 100 violations for lack of deadbolts, but James Heiberg said to delete those violations. 
4. All communications between anyone from Code Enforcement and anyone at AIDS Healthcare Foundation, regarding the deadbolts at the Baltimore.  This is including but not limited to the text messages and emails that Robert Gilardi kindly sends to Mark Dyer rather than issuing a Notice to Comply. This includes communications between Code Enforcement on the one hand, and on the other hand,  AHF's: Mark Dyer, Michael Weinstein, Jonathan Eisenberg, Tom Myers, Conrad Sison, Beatrice Di Marco, Dominique Eastman, Herbert Ellis,  Juan Larios.
5. Any discussion (including emails, text messages, memos, notes) between any Code Enforcement employee, (including but not limited to James Heiberg, Robert Gilardi, Tony Robles, Ann Sewill, etc.), that includes any of the following terms: "1941.3" "deadbolt" "dead bolt" "91.8607" "door lock" "91.8607" and/or "897099." 
6. Any discussion between any Code Enforcement employee, about why it decided to exclude the exact complaint language from the publicly accessible Property Activity Report on complaint #897099.
7. Any emails with the subject line "Complaint # 897099 / Baltimore Hotel / Carlos Brum/ Lack of Deadbolts"

This public records act request is not limited to the custodian of records simply forwarding this request to the named individuals here. This request demands that the custodian of records actually contact its IT department and conduct a search with the specific parameters and search terms. This request demands electronic copies of these records in their native format, and not printed out and scanned.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Annette Morasch

title: Missouri AG BJC-Saint Luke's (Office of the Attorney General - Missouri)

communications.subject: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request: Missouri AG BJC-Saint Luke's (Office of the Attorney General - Missouri)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Missouri Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

All documents and written communication including, and relating to, the merger review of BJC HealthCare and Saint Luke's Health System. 

The requested information may include but is not limited to: emails, call logs, text messages, copies of documents reviewed, transcripts of interviews, letter of intent, and definitive agreement.

I'm also requesing access to all documents and written communication between the Office of the Attorney General of Missouri and the Federal Trade Commission regarding the merger between BJC HealthCare and Saint Luke's Health System. Since the merger was proposed earlier this year, the date range for this record search should be between May 1, 2023 to November 29, 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samantha Liss

communications.subject: RE: 23-755 Liss RE: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request #23-755
communications.communication:
Ms. Liss,

Thank you for your question. The letter you received was a good faith estimate of the time it will take to fulfill your sunshine request as required by section 610.023.3 of Missouri’s Sunshine Law.  As explained in the letter, the estimate takes into account, among other things, the sheer volume of requests received by our office. We process sunshine requests as quickly as possible in the order they are received. Because we process the requests in the order they are received, whether you amend your request, which you are welcome to do, or keep it as is, it does not change its position in the queue. As our previous letter stated, there are currently 288 open sunshine requests, many of which require the review of hundreds of thousands of pages. In addition, we receive numerous emails and additional requests each day. Your request is important to us and will be processed as soon as it reaches the front of the line. We are reviewing and releasing records as quickly as possible, and we appreciate your continued patience.
Best,
Nicki

Nicki Eatinger-Sprague | Custodian of Records
Missouri Attorney General's Office

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Chicago Crime Commission
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records relating to, mentioning, or generated as a result of interaction with or investigation of the Chicago Crime Commission.

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies. If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Paul Galante

communications.communication:
# Individual Information

Prefix First Name Middle Name Last Name Suffix Email Phone Location

# Domestic Address

Address Line 1 Address Line 2 City State Postal

# Agreement to Pay

How you will pay

I am limiting my request to the free two hours of searching and 100 duplicated
pages. I am not willing to pay additional fees.

# Non-Individual FOIA Request

Request Information

    
    
    To Whom It May Concern:
    
    Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following
    records:
    
    Records relating to, mentioning, or generated as a result of interaction
    with or investigation of the Chicago Crime Commission.
    
    Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not
    limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone
    Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and
    the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and
    cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and
    companies. If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or
    transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer
    slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or
    describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to
    confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If
    previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release
    consisting of those records while additional records are located and
    processed for release.
    
    The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and
    this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
    
    In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me
    of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the
    request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM
    if not.
    
    Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look
    forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days,
    as the statute requires.
    
    Sincerely,
    
    Paul Galante
    
    Upload documents directly:
    https://https://www.muckrock.comhttps://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?url_auth_token=AAAj2ProGzquHYFeb-SMkiAXsEc%3A1ihpzr%3A4W690-hC6nbEO30ZXmBWcJm35_g&next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Ffederal-bureau-of-investigation-10%252Fchicago-crime-commission-84595%252F%253Femail%253Dfoipaquestions%252540ic.fbi.gov

** 

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to
foipaquestions@fbi.gov. If you have received a FOIPA request number, please
include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

** 

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBI’s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBI’s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the ‘Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request tool’ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1455119-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 152 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 922 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,964 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 2,360 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1455119-001
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on “Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request” on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request

If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-0] please enter [1195846-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-1] please enter [1195846-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000
Case Type:
FOIPA
Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)

The FBI’s FOIPA Program is searching the FBI’s indices for potentially responsive documents.

You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.


Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system, and the FBI receives a voluminous amount of requests on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Our complex requests are further divided into small (51-250 pages), medium (251-500 pages), large (501-4,999), and extra-large (over 5,000 pages) sub-tracks.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  The more potentially responsive pages a request has, the more complex it becomes, greatly increasing the time required for processing. Generally, the larger the file, the longer it takes to process.
Currently, simple track cases average approximately 230 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Complex requests in the small processing track are currently averaging 1,085 days from the date of receipt for processing, those in the medium processing track are currently averaging 1,310 days, those in the large processing track are currently averaging approximately 2,010 days, and those in the extra-large track are averaging 2,370 days  .


Respectfully,


Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Saturday Night Live FCC complaints
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All complaints received regarding Saturday Night Live on NBC from January 1, 2023, until February 12, 2024.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brooke Germain

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: California Department of Transportation’s Maintenance Policy Directive 1001-R1
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

California Department of Transportation’s Maintenance Policy Directive 1001-R1

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robbie Powelson

communications.subject: [Records Center] Welcome to the Public Records Center!
communications.communication:
Dear Robbie Powelson, 
Thank you for registering with the Caltrans Public Records Center. If you have never used this system, your account has been created by a staff person at Caltrans. 

Once your email address has been verified, you can log in to the Public Records Center to update any contact or password information and to track the progress of your request. Login: 170187-62225737@requests.muckrock.com 

To verify your email address, the following activation link to set a password will be active for 24 hours. 
Activate Online Account 

If the activation link expires, you will need to request a password by clicking the link below. This will allow you to access your request, manage account information, and retrieve responsive records. communications.subject: [Records Center] Public Records Request :: R033839-072524
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

RE: Public Records Request of July 25, 2024, Reference # R033839-072524

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Unclaimed Bail Funds
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

A spreadsheet or spreadsheets of currently and previously unclaimed funds held by of Office of the State Comptroller at any point from 2014 through 2023, in which the "type of property" is "bail funds," in .xls, .xlsx, or .csv format.

Please ensure that the following information is included in individual columns: unclaimed bail fund's amount, owner name, owner address, reported by, reported as, number of owners, type of property, OUF code, and year reported.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

New York Focus

All will-serve letters (conditional or otherwise) from public water systems for the Prairie View Ranch Planned Development and/or modular homes within the Development.

Good Afternoon,
Our Planning and Zoning Department has determined that this request will take approximately four hours to fulfill.  The Morgan County CORA Request policy states that the first hour is free and then each additional hour is $33.58. We would ask for a deposit of half to initiate the appropriate work. The overall total would be $134.32 with $67.16 being due before work begins.  I forgot to mention that if the number of hours is less than anticipated, you will not be charged and/or refunded.

I have attached the normal CORA form for your information of our policies.  If you have any questions, we're glad to help. Please reach out to my contacts below. Thank you!

Kevin Strauch
Morgan County Clerk and Recorder
kstrauch@co.morgan.co.us
(970)542-3522

Good Morning,
I have reattached a copy of Morgan County's CORA request policy for your
records. As stated in our policy: "The normal time for production shall be
three working days, beginning on the first business day after the request
is received or upon receipt of deposit of the estimated costs as determined
by the custodian, whichever is later." The previous estimate was based upon
no fees being needed. The current estimate will be within three days of
receipt of the payment. When we receive it, we will reach out and let you
know so that we all can have an adjusted timeline to go from. Planning and
Zoning is aware of the request so they should hopefully be able to find the
documents ASAP. Thank you for your patience. For convenience and tracking
of both requests, I will respond to both of them with this message. Have a
great day.

Kevin Strauch

I have reached out to Muckrock staff to see how they would like us to handle it but please make sure you receive a refund of $167.90. I have also attached the files to this message if that would be a preferred way to received them. Please reach out to kstrauch@co.morgan.co.us if you have any questions. Thank you. 

Kevin Strauch
Morgan County Clerk and Recorder

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Request: NARA-Nixon Library Communications
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

This is a request under the Freedom of Information Act.  I hereby request the following records:

All communications (emails, text messages, etcs) between NARA staff and the Nixon Library, for the week of May 8th-12th, 2017.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.


Sincerely,

JPat Brown

communications.subject: NGC17-390 Nixon Library Communications
communications.communication:
*RE: NGC17-390   FOIAonline: **NARA-NGC-2017-000583 *

MuckRock
DEPT MR 37822
411A Highland Ave
Somerville, MA 02144-2516

Dear JPat Brown,

Thank you for submitting the attached FOIA request.

We need your help in narrowing the scope of your FOIA request, as we launch
our search for responsive documents.

You requested the following: All communications (emails, text messages,
etcs) between NARA staff and the Nixon Library, for the week of May
8th-12th, 2017.

Because we have thousands of employees, which NARA staff are you referring?
Likewise, are there specific staff at the Nixon Library you are referring
to as well?

This information would be very helpful in narrowing your request and
speeding up the process of gathering responsive documents.

Thank you,


Wanda Williams
Deputy Freedom of Information Act Officer/Archivist
National Archives and Records Administration
Office of General Counsel
College Park, Maryland
301-837-0773

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Request #NARA-NGC-2017-000583
communications.communication:
Hello!
Thanks so much for reaching out - I'm mainly interested in the communications with the social media manager and their supervisors - I apologize for my naivete, I just thought that the number of communications between NARA and the Nixon Library would be rather limited.
All the best,
JPat

and the Office of General Counsel's internal tracking number NGC17-390.

Your case is currently 69 in our queue.

For many of our complex cases that take more than 20 days to process,
responsive documents have been referred to other federal agencies

communications.subject: Re: Freedom of Information Request #NARA-NGC-2017-000583
communications.communication:
*RE: NGC17-390  NARA-NGC-2017-000583 *

Dear JPat Brown,

Thank you for contacting our office for an update on your FOIA request.

Your request, NGC17-390, is currently #68 in our queue. You case was also
assigned FOIAonline tracking number NARA-NGC-2017-000583, we currently
track cases using two different databases.
Your case is complex and for many of our complex cases that take more than 20
days to process, responsive documents have been sent out to other federal
agencies for consultation.

As we await a response, we are able to process cases lower in our queue that
are not awaiting outside consultation. ​ We have identified and gathered
all the responsive documents for your case and expect your case could be
one of those we can complete ahead of cases awaiting consultations.

We expect to process your case within the next 6 to 12 months, we apologize
for the delay.

Thank you,



Wanda Williams
Deputy Freedom of Information Act Officer/Archivist
National Archives and Records Administration
Office of General Counsel
College Park, Maryland
301-837-0773

communications.subject: NGC17-390 Response to FOIA Request
communications.communication:
Dear JPat Brown:


This is in response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request dated
May 18, 2017.  Your request was received in our office on the same day and
assigned FOIA tracking number NGC17-390.  We apologize for the long delay
in responding to our request.  Please see the attached correspondence and
records responsive to your FOIA request.

Sincerely,


Jodi L. Foor

Deputy Freedom of Information Act Officer

National Archives and Records Administration

NARA Operational FOIA and Access Division

College Park, MD

301-837-2099

Jodi.Foor@nara.gov

title: Harrison Homes Permits at Prairie View Ranch

communications.subject: Colorado Open Records Act Request: Harrison Homes Permits at Prairie View Ranch
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Colorado Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All types of permits issued by Morgan County for new roadworks, new electrical infrastructure, new water infrastructure, new transportation infrastructure, new garages/workshops, new foundations, new septic systems, and new modular home installation activities carried out at the Prairie View Ranch Planned Development from 2017 to present. The purpose of this request is to assemble a clear picture of who applied for permits, which permits were denied or approved, and who performed the permitted or denied work.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Anonymous natural person(s)

Our Planning and Zoning Department has determined that this request will take approximately six hours to fulfill.  The Morgan County CORA Request policy states that the first hour is free and then each additional hour is $33.58. We would ask for a deposit of half to initiate the appropriate work. The overall total would be $167.90 with $83.95 being due before work begins. If you have any questions, we're glad to help. Please reach out to my contacts below. Thank you!

Kevin Strauch

communications.subject: RE: Colorado Open Records Act Request #PVR-1
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I'm following up on the following Colorado Open Records Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on July 13, 2024. You had previously indicated that it would be completed on July 18, 2024. I wanted to check on the status of my request, and to see if there was a new estimated completion date.  You had assigned it reference number #PVR-1.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: Re: Colorado Open Records Act Request #PVR-1
communications.communication:
Good Morning,
I have reattached a copy of Morgan County's CORA request policy for your
records. As stated in our policy: "The normal time for production shall be
three working days, beginning on the first business day after the request
is received or upon receipt of deposit of the estimated costs as determined
by the custodian, whichever is later." The previous estimate was based upon
no fees being needed. The current estimate will be within three days of
receipt of the payment. When we receive it, we will reach out and let you
know so that we all can have an adjusted timeline to go from. Planning and
Zoning is aware of the request so they should hopefully be able to find the
documents ASAP. Thank you for your patience. For convenience and tracking
of both requests, I will respond to both of them with this message. Have a
great day.

Kevin Strauch

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Christina Pushaw's Calendar
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

The calendar of Press Secretary Christina Pushaw from the date of her hire until the end of her tenure. I request that the records be released in electronic format, preferably as an export from Microsoft Outlook or whatever similar software is used by the office.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Ben Welsh

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Christina Pushaw's Calendar
communications.communication:
Good morning,

The Governor’s Office of Open Government is in receipt of your request for records as stated in your email below. If there is a fee associated with your request, you will be provided with a fee estimate for your review. Thank you for contacting the Executive Office of the Governor.

Sincerely,
Office of Open Government

communications.communication:
Good morning Ben,

To clarify, would you like to include cancelled meetings/appointments within your search?

Sincerely,
Office of Open Government

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Christina Pushaw's Calendar
communications.communication: If it does not add significant time to the processing of the request, please include them.

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Christina Pushaw's Calendar
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,



The Governor’s Office of Open Government has initiated a search for records responsive to your request, a copy of which is below.



Our initial search has found over 8,000 items potentially responsive to your request. An item identifies an email, attachment, meeting invitation, etc., and each item could result in multiple pages. All responsive pages require review for exempt and/or confidential information.



The Executive Office of the Governor is committed to public transparency and compliance with Florida’s Sunshine laws, and we will work to process your request as quickly as possible.  As you may know, complex or laborious requests that may require significant staff review or materials costs are subject to service charges.



Please let us know if you would like to limit the scope of your request.  Please note, if we do not hear from you within 30 days, our office will consider your request closed. Should that occur, you would be welcome to re-submit your request at any time.



Sincerely,

Open Government

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Christina Pushaw's Calendar
communications.communication: Can you give me a price estimate for this request?

communications.subject: RE: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Christina Pushaw's Calendar
communications.communication:
Good afternoon Ben,

Using our hourly rates for estimated legal review and staff resources for 8,450 items with no attachments, the total cost is $2,044.94. You would be required to pay 50% of this as an initial labor deposit which would come out to $1,022.47. However, your request did result in emails with attachments meaning there would be an additional cost. If you would like an official labor deposit for the exact amount this would cost, our office would need to convert the 8,450 items into page numbers with attachments included. To do so for this amount of items would take an significant amount of time with our software. Again, you are welcome to narrow the scope of your request at any time.

Sincerely,
Office of Open Government

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Patron Incident Reports - February
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

All Patron Incident Reports submitted for the Area Manager 5 North Region in February 2024.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alexandra Gelzin

Alexandra Gelzin

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: St Vitus
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Public reports state that St. Vitus music venue (1120 Manhattan Ave, Brooklyn) was shut down in February by Department of Buildings: https://nypost.com/2024/02/19/us-news/iconic-brooklyn-metal-bar-saint-vitus-shuttered-over-building-violation/. Therefore, I request the following:

1) All complaints, assessments, presentations, photos, videos, and communications that mention "Vitus" or relate to 1120 Manhattan Ave, Brooklyn 


Please search for documents created or shared between June 1, 2023 and the time this request is processed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jason Koebler

communications.subject: Department of Buildings FOIL Request
communications.communication:
Dear Jason,

I work in the Press Office at the Department of Buildings, and I was forwarded your FOIL request by a member of the Department who manages FOIL requests.

In the interest of expediency, wanted to share some information on the Department's recent enforcement actions at the St. Vitus Bar. See below:


  *   On 2/16/24, DOB conducted an inspection of 1120 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, in response to over a dozen 311 complaints from members of the public about the location.
  *   Upon our arrival to the scene, we found approximately 250 people on the first floor of the building, assembled in an illegal eating and drink establishment.
  *   The Certificate of Occupancy for the building indicates that the first floor of this building is supposed be used for a commercial store and for the storage of machinery.
  *   As a result of our inspection we issued a violation to the property owner for operating the unpermitted place of assembly, contrary to the legal occupancy of the building.
  *   During our inspection, DOB did not issue a Vacate Order at the building. The building can still be occupied.
  *   This is the second time we have issued a violation to 1120 Manhattan Avenue for this issue. We previously issued a similar violation to the property owner on 7/21/23.
  *   That July 2023 violation remains unresolved, as the property owners never corrected the issue. That is why they were issued another violation by DOB on February 16th.
  *   If the property owner wishes to legally operate the club, they can obtain permits to legally convert the space and obtain a new Certificate of Occupancy from DOB.

For more details on the above and for other information you may be seeking on this matter, you can use the Department's Building Information System (BIS) which is publicly available.

If you visit BIS and type the address of St Vitus Bar (1120 Manhattan Ave, Brooklyn) you will be directed to this page: https://a810-bisweb.nyc.gov/bisweb/PropertyProfileOverviewServlet?boro=3&houseno=1120&street=Manhattan+Ave&go2=+GO+&requestid=0

From there, you can view all 311 complaints: https://a810-bisweb.nyc.gov/bisweb/ComplaintsByAddressServlet?requestid=1&allbin=3063704

As well as DOB violations: https://a810-bisweb.nyc.gov/bisweb/ActionsByLocationServlet?requestid=1&allbin=3063704&allinquirytype=BXS4OCV3&stypeocv3=V

Please let me know if the information provided here is sufficient to fulfill your FOIL request. If it is, we will close out the request. If you would like to leave it open and move forward with the FOIL request, please let us know in your response.
Best,
David Maggiotto
Deputy Press Secretary
NYC Department of Buildings
(929) 512-0051

The Department of Buildings (DOB) has closed your FOIL request FOIL-2024-810-00731 for the following reasons: (https://a860-openrecords.nyc.gov/request/view/FOIL-2024-810-00731) 
 Your request under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) has been fulfilled and the documents you requested have been emailed to you. Please refer to the email sent to you on February 21, 2024 from our NYC DOB Press Office regarding responsive documents according to your request.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Department of Defense support for 2022 film "Come Out Fighting"
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any documents pertaining to collaboration between the Department of Defense (DoD) and the production of the 2022 movie "Come Out Fighting," directed by Steven Luke. I request any and all documents pertaining to DoD involvement with the production of "Come Out Fighting." Such documents may include but should not be limited to: script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of DoD and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "Come Out Fighting," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication.

Attached is a list, released to me through FOIA by Dod, of TV and movie productions supported by DoD in 2023; "Come Out Fighting" is included on this list.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Neil J. Welch
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The personnel file of Neil J. Welch (August 9, 1926 - June 29, 2017), who was an FBI employee from 1951 to 1980.  Welch served as Special Agent-in-Charge for a number of field offices including Buffalo in 1966, Detroit, Philadelphia in 1975, and New York in 1978 until his retirement. Proof of death is not required as his death was widely reported: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/11/us/politics/neil-welch-dead-fbi-abscam-kitty-genovese.html

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Paul Galante

Supporting documentation **

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to
foipaquestions@fbi.gov. If you have received a FOIPA request number, please
include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

** 

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBI’s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBI’s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the ‘Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request tool’ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1487260-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 152 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 922 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,964 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 2,360 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Samuel Loring Morison
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning or describing Samuel Loring Morison.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emma North-Best

communications.subject: eFOIA Request Received
communications.communication:
# Individual Information

Prefix First Name Middle Name Last Name Suffix Email Phone Location

# Domestic Address

Address Line 1 Address Line 2 City State Postal

# Agreement to Pay

How you will pay

I am requesting a fee waiver for my request and have reviewed the FOIA
reference guide. If my fee waiver is denied, I would like to limit my request
to the two free hours of searching and 100 duplicated pages.

# Proof Of Affiliation for Fee Waiver

Waiver Explanation

    
    
    I am a member of the news media and request classification as such. I have
    previously written
    about the government and its activities, with some reaching over 100,000
    readers in outlets such
    as Gizmodo, MuckRock, Motherboard, Property of the People, Unicorn Riot, and
    The Outline,
    among others. As such, as I have a reasonable expectation of publication and
    my editorial and
    writing skills are well established. In addition, I discuss and comment on
    the files online and
    make them available through non-profits such as the library Internet Archive
    and the journalist
    non-profit MuckRock, disseminating them to a large audience. While my
    research is not limited
    to this, a great deal of it, including this, focuses on the activities and
    attitudes of the government
    itself. As such, it is not necessary for me to demonstrate the relevance of
    this particular subject in
    advance.
    Further, case law states that â€œproof of the ability to disseminate the
    released information to a
    broad cross- section of the public is not required.â€� Judicial Watch, Inc. v.
    Depâ€™t of Justice, 365
    F.3d 1108, 1126 (D.C. Cir. 2004); see Carney v. U.S. Depâ€™t of Justice, 19 F.
    3d 807, 814-15 (2d
    Cir. 1994). Further, courts have held that "qualified because it also had
    â€œfirmâ€� plans to â€œpublish a
    number of . . . â€˜document setsâ€™â€� concerning United States foreign and
    national security policy."
    Under this criteria, as well, I qualify as a member of the news media.
    Additionally, courts have held that the news media status "focuses on the
    nature of the requester,
    not its request. The provision requires that the request be â€œmade byâ€� a
    representative of the news
    media. Id. Â§ 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II). A newspaper reporter, for example, is a
    representative of the
    news media regardless of how much interest there is in the story for which
    he or she is requesting
    information." As such, the details of the request itself are moot for the
    purposes of determining
    the appropriate fee category.
    As my primary purpose is to inform about government activities by reporting
    on it and making
    the raw data available, I request that fees be waived.
    This request specifically includes both previously processed and previously
    unprocessed
    documents. If the documents are 25 or more years old and previously
    processed documents were
    processed before the 25th anniversary of the documentâ€™s creation, I request
    that in addition to the
    previous processed copy, the document be reprocessed and redactions
    reviewed.

Documentation Files

# Deceased Individual

Prefix First Name Middle Name Last Name Suffix ARN SSN FBI Number Date of
Birth Place of Birth Date of Death Additional Information

    
    
    To Whom It May Concern:
    
    Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following
    records:
    
    Records mentioning or describing Samuel Loring Morison.
    
    The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and
    this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
    
    In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me
    of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the
    request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM
    if not.
    
    Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look
    forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days,
    as the statute requires.
    
    Sincerely,
    
    Emma North-Best
    
    Attachments:
    
    
    https://cdn.muckrock.com/outbound_composer_attachments/EmmaBest/121157/Fee_category_and_search_parameters.pdf
    
    https://cdn.muckrock.com/outbound_composer_attachments/EmmaBest/121157/Samuel_Loring_Morison_1944-2018_-_Find_a_Grave_Memorial.pdf
    
    https://cdn.muckrock.com/outbound_composer_attachments/EmmaBest/121157/Morison_Convicted_of_Spying_Stealing_Navy_Documents_-_The_Washington_Post.pdf
    Upload documents directly:
    https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Ffederal-bureau-of-investigation-10%252Fsamuel-loring-morison-144958%252F%253Femail%253Defoia%252540subscriptions.fbi.gov&url_auth_token=AAAj2OEi3pjuv1arI66uoG-O4gc%3A1prFlw%3AsNS4o2ppme-6SsH4okeer1mP280_dU00ip20NJZhwCM

Supporting documentation **

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to
foipaquestions@fbi.gov. If you have received a FOIPA request number, please
include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

** 

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBIâ€™s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBIâ€™s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the â€˜Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request toolâ€™ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.
The request has been rejected, with the agency stating that it can neither confirm nor deny the existence of the requested documents.

communications.subject: Response to ATF FOIA Request
communications.communication:
April 16, 2024                                REFER TO:  2024-01020 (ATF) 
FBI FOI/PA # 1590533-000 

Ms. Emma Best 
411A Highland Avenue 
Somerville, Massachusetts  02144-2516 

Dear Ms. Best: 

While processing your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request dated April 25, 2023, for records concerning Samuel Loring Morison, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) referred three pages of records to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) for processing and direct response to you.  The documents were received by ATF on April 3, 2024, and this referral was assigned ATF tracking number 2024-01020.  Please refer to this number in any future correspondence with this office.  For your reference, the FBI file number associated with this request is FBI FOI/PA # 1590533-000. 

For your information, this office assigns incoming requests to one of three tracks:  simple, complex, or expedited.  Each request is then handled on a first-in, first-out basis in relation to other requests in the same track.  Simple requests usually receive a response in approximately one month, whereas complex requests necessarily take longer.  At this time, your request has been assigned to the Simple track.  You may wish to narrow the scope of your request to limit the number of potentially responsive records or agree to an alternative time frame for processing, should records be located; or you may wish to await the completion of our records search to discuss either of these options. 

We determined that you are a representative of the news media pursuant to 5 U.S.C. section  552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II).  As such, we are required to assess fees for duplication of responsive records.  See 28 C.F.R. section 16.10(c).  You may review the Department of Justice regulations, which establish the fees charged for processing FOIA requests at http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/granule/FR-2015-04-03/2015-07772.  If you disagree with this determination, you are welcome to provide any additional information that would demonstrate that you should not be considered a representative of the news media requester.  If you would like to discuss either the track or the fees associated with your request, please contact our FOIA Public Liaisons, Lynette Carter and Jasmine Bryant, at 202-648-7390.  You may also discuss any aspect of your request with our FOIA Public Liaison. 

Sincerely, 

Elizabeth A. Wood 
Acting Chief 
Information and Privacy Governance Division
A copy of documents responsive to the request.

communications.subject: Response to ATF FOIA Request 2019-1161 (267171)
communications.communication:
07/25/2024								REFER TO:  2019-1161 (267171) 

Ms. Emma Best 
411A Highland Avenue 
Somerville, Massachusetts  02144-2516 

Dear Ms. Best: 

This responds to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) dated 6/26/2019, and received by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) on the same date, in which you requested records concerning creation of the FOIA office.  Your request was assigned ATF tracking number 2019-1161 (267171).  Please refer to this number in any future correspondence. 

In response to your request, I am providing you with the requested information.  Your request is granted in full.  I hope you find this information helpful. 

For your information, Congress excluded three discrete categories of law enforcement and national security records from the requirements of the FOIA.  See 5 U.S.C. § 552(c).  This response is limited to those records that are subject to the requirements of the FOIA.  This is a standard notification that is given to all our requesters and should not be taken as an indication that excluded records do, or do not, exist. 

You may contact our FOIA Public Liaisons, Lynette Carter and Jasmine Bryant, at 202-648-7390, for any further assistance and to discuss any aspect of your request. 

Sincerely, 

Hirsh D. Kravitz 
Acting Chief 
Information and Privacy Governance Division

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

Dear Rose Terse: 
Thank you for your interest in public records of Washington State Department of Transportation. Your request has been received and is being processed in accordance with the State of Washington Public Records Act, Chapter 42.56 RCW. Your request was received in this office on 4/25/2024 and given the reference number P015012-042524 for tracking purposes. Records Requested: To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I received an index of emails between WSDOT and Flock Safety in P014550-030324. Please provide all emails in this index, along with associated attachments and metadata.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fdepartment-transportation-468%252Fflock-safety-emails-162685%252F%253Femail%253Dpublicdisclosurerequests%252540wsdot.wa.gov&url_auth_token=AAAXlhbWT9mG7-EtXl62vYSLWiY%3A1s0Abn%3AImYCMeUIO5Yugs5H0X8ZnRwX_fzkf5Zv-zHw7KQ1n-o 
Not all public documents are available in electronic format. If the document(s) requested are not available electronically, we will make them available for inspection or by paper copy in accordance with the Public Records Act, Chapter 42.56 RCW. 
 
Your request will be forwarded to the relevant department(s) to locate the information you seek and to determine the volume and any costs associated with satisfying your request. You will be contacted about the availability and/or provided with copies of the records in question. PLEASE NOTE: The State of Washington Public Records Act, Chapter 42.56 RCW, does not require a governmental body to create new information, to do legal research, or to answer questions. 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. Again, thank you for using the Public Disclosure Request Center. 
Washington State Department of Transportation

After reviewing your request as written and our current workload, we estimate it will take 6 months to produce all the records you are seeking. However, during that time we will release records to you in installments as they become available. 
Our procedure is to determine the office(s) where requested records are located. We then work with staff to identify and gather the responsive records. 
Once records are located and gathered, we review them for information that may be redacted based on a statutory exemption. In some cases, we may require additional time to notify a third party or consult with legal counsel. 
We will check in periodically with you to provide a status update, but please feel free to reach out at any time if you should have questions or concerns. 
We look forward to working with you, 

Dawn Roberts 
Public Disclosure Coordinator 
Washington State Department of Transportation

title: Illinois DOC - constituent services (Department of Corrections)

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Illinois DOC - constituent services (Department of Corrections)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

I hope this request finds you in good spirits. I request that a copy of the following documents [or documents containing the following information] be provided to me that pertains to your facilities:  

Please provide the records requested below for June 2023 to June 2024. 

* Number of complaints received by Constituent Services (monthly and yearly).
* Type of complaints received by Constituent Services.
* Resolution of complaints received by Constituent Services (i.e., investigated, transferred). By type and category, both monthly and yearly.
* Number of employees in Constituent Services (monthly and yearly).
* Employee position/title in Constituent Services (monthly and yearly).
* Names, titles, and direct contact information for each Consituent Services employee (as of June 2024), including extensions.
* Names of agencies and/or organizations consulted or collaborated with, in order to resolve complaints (monthly, yearly).
* Outcome of complaints which were resolved with the assistance of other agencies, offices, and organizations (monthly, yearly).
* Length of time for resolution of complaints (monthly and yearly).
* Number of repeated complaints filed by same constituent (monthly and yearly).
* Number of complaints by facility (monthly and yearly).
* Number of complaints resulting in IDOC employee suspension or dismissal (monthly and yearly).

In the event that there are fees, please inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request be filled electronically.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Laurel King Russell

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Jamestown PD Grant Applications
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Jamestown Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Gelardi

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Jamestown PD Grant Applications
communications.communication:
Dear Chris Gelardi:

This will acknowledge receipt of your request for records under the Freedom of Information Law received by the Division of Criminal Justice Services on March 22, 2024. The request was for "All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Jamestown Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present."

Your request has been forwarded to the appropriate program area(s) to identify documents that are responsive to your request and which may be made available pursuant to all applicable provisions of the Freedom of Information Law.



A determination as to whether your request is granted or denied will be reached in approximately 20 business days or we will notify you in writing if the responsible program area(s) should require additional time to locate, assemble and review documents that may be responsive to your request.



Please note that, pursuant to Article 6 of the Public Officers Law, a charge may be applied to your request, including the actual cost of the medium used to respond to your Freedom of Information Law request and/or other related costs.  When responsive records have been identified, you will be informed of any cost and how payment should be made.







Very truly yours,


Brian Garvey, Esq.
Records Access Officer

This is in response to your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request for "All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Jamestown Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present."

Pursuant to POL §89(4)(a), you may appeal this determination within 30 days to the Counsel, Division of Criminal Justice Services, 80 South Swan St., Albany, NY 12210 or by email at foil@dcjs.ny.gov<mailto:foil@dcjs.ny.gov>.

Brian Garvey, Esq.

title: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Police "Referral" Definition

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Police "Referral" Definition
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am reaching out in reference to a prior request for public records in the custody of your organization. I work with Erin Stewart at the Center for Public Interest Advocacy & Collaboration, an educational, research and advocacy organization at Northeastern University School of Law. 

In June 2022, Susan Tkaczuk fulfilled Erin’s request for school-based arrest data, including referrals to law enforcement. The records we received are attached for reference. We request clarification of the definition of “referral” used by your police department, including the process for a referral and how it differs from an arrest. 

If you have any questions about this request or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response.

Sincerely,

Norrie Osgood
Research Assistant
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law
osgood.n@northeastern.edu 
(603) 848-2018

I would like to obtain all email records sent to, sent from, or copied to the email accounts of David Sean Ferriero or Debra Steidel Wall from January 1, 2015 to Present Day that contain the non-case sensitive keyword "Whistleblower". If needed, I may be able to provide a Privacy Act release. Also, if this request is too vague, please let me know and I would be happy to reduce the scope or provide additional/more specific search parameters. Should you need any more information or if this request is too broad, please let me know and I will be happy to provide more information. The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Taylor Amarel
